title: Using missRanger
text: {missRanger} multivariate imputation algorithm based random forests. fast alternative beautiful ‘MissForest’ algorithm Stekhoven Buehlmann (2011), uses {ranger} package (Wright Ziegler 2017) fit random forests. algorithm iterates average --bag (OOB) error forests stops improving. missing values filled OOB predictions best iteration. {missRanger} fast. allows --sample applications. intuitive: E.g., calling missRanger(data, . ~ 1) impute variables univariately, missRanger(data, Species ~ Sepal.Width) use Sepal.Width impute Species. works variety data types. combines random forest imputation predictive mean matching. avoids “new” values like 0.3334 0-1 coded variable helps raise variance imputations, especially important multiple imputation (see additional vignettes).

title: Using missRanger
code: # From CRAN install.packages("missRanger")  # Development version devtools::install_github("mayer79/missRanger")

title: Using missRanger
text: worked, new values appear overly exact. avoid , can add predictive mean matching (PMM) OOB predictions:
code: imp <- missRanger(iris_NA, pmm.k = 5, num.trees = 100, verbose = 0) head(imp) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.4         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

title: Using missRanger
text: missRanger() offers many options. use one feature per split (mtry = 1) 200 trees?
code: imp <- missRanger(iris_NA, pmm.k = 5, num.trees = 200, mtry = 1, verbose = 0)

title: Using missRanger
text: Setting data_only = FALSE (keep_forests = TRUE) returns “missRanger” object. keep_forests = TRUE, allows --sample applications:
code: imp <- missRanger(   iris_NA, pmm.k = 5, num.trees = 100, keep_forests = TRUE, verbose = 0 ) imp #> missRanger object. Extract imputed data via $data #> - best iteration: 3  #> - best average OOB imputation error: 0.1468982  summary(imp) #> missRanger object. Extract imputed data via $data #> - best iteration: 3  #> - best average OOB imputation error: 0.1468982  #>  #> Sequence of OOB prediction errors: #>  #>      Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width    Species #> [1,]    1.0000000   1.1108502   0.39671941  0.18322253 0.06666667 #> [2,]    0.2224743   0.5371919   0.06000731  0.05568752 0.03703704 #> [3,]    0.1732113   0.4517314   0.02408501  0.05583381 0.02962963 #> [4,]    0.1796650   0.4715697   0.02106975  0.05502143 0.03703704 #>  #> Mean performance per iteration: #> [1] 0.5514918 0.1824796 0.1468982 0.1528726 #>  #> First rows of imputed data: #>  #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa  # Out-of-sample application # saveRDS(imp, file = "imputation_model.rds") # imp <- readRDS("imputation_model.rds") predict(imp, head(iris_NA)) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.1         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

title: Using missRanger
text: default, missRanger() uses columns impute columns missings. can modified passing formula: left hand side specifies variables imputed, right hand side lists variables used imputation.
code: # Impute all variables with all (default) m <- missRanger(iris_NA, formula = . ~ ., pmm.k = 5, num.trees = 100, verbose = 0)  # Don't use Species for imputation m <- missRanger(iris_NA, . ~ . - Species, pmm.k = 5, num.trees = 100, verbose = 0)  # Impute Sepal.Length by Species (or not?) m <- missRanger(iris_NA, Sepal.Length ~ Species, pmm.k = 5, num.trees = 100) #>  #> Variables to impute:     Sepal.Length #> Variables used to impute:     #>  #> iter 1  #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |======================================================================| 100% head(m) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4          NA  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2    <NA> #> 5          6.2         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4    <NA>  # Only univariate imputation was done! Why? Because Species contains missing values # itself and needs to appear on the LHS as well: m <- missRanger(iris_NA, Sepal.Length + Species ~ Species, pmm.k = 5, num.trees = 100) #>  #> Variables to impute:     Sepal.Length, Species #> Variables used to impute:    Species #>  #> iter 1  #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |===================================                                   |  50%  |                                                                              |======================================================================| 100% head(m) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width    Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2     setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4          NA     setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2     setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2 versicolor #> 5          6.5         3.6          1.4         0.2     setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4 versicolor  # Impute all variables univariately m <- missRanger(iris_NA, . ~ 1, verbose = 0)

title: Using missRanger
text: missRanger() fits random forest per variable iteration. Thus, imputation can take long. tweaks: Use less trees, e.g., num.trees = 100. Use smaller tree depth, e.g., max.depth = 6. Use large leaves, e.g., min.node.size = 100. Use smaller bootstrap samples, e.g., sample.fraction = 0.2. Use less iterations, e.g., max.iter = 3. first three items also help greatly reduce size models, might become relevant --sample applications keep_forests = TRUE.

what: Trick: Use case.weights to reduce impact of rows with many missings
title: Using missRanger
text: Using case.weights argument, can pass case weights imputation models. instance, allows reduce contribution rows many missings:
code: m <- missRanger(   iris_NA,   num.trees = 100,   pmm.k = 5,   case.weights = rowSums(!is.na(iris_NA)) )

what: How to use {missRanger} for multiple imputation?
title: Multiple Imputation
text: statistical inference, extra variability introduced imputation accounted . usually done multiple imputation. One standard approaches impute dataset multiple times, generating, e.g., 10 100 versions complete data. , intended analysis (t-test, linear model etc.) performed datasets. results pooled, usually Rubin’s rule (Rubin 1987): Parameter estimates averaged. variances avaraged well, corrected upwards adding variance parameter estimates across imputations. package {mice} (Buuren Groothuis-Oudshoorn 2011) takes care pooling step. creation multiple complete data sets can done {mice} also {missRanger}. latter case, order keep variance imputed values realistic level, suggest use predictive mean matching relatively large pmm.k top random forest imputation.

title: Multiple Imputation
text: expected, inference multiple imputation seems less strong original data without missings.
code: library(missRanger) library(mice)  set.seed(19)  iris_NA <- generateNA(iris, p = c(0, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1))  # Generate 20 complete data sets with relatively large pmm.k filled <- replicate(   20,    missRanger(iris_NA, verbose = 0, num.trees = 100, pmm.k = 10),    simplify = FALSE )                             # Run a linear model for each of the completed data sets                           models <- lapply(filled, function(x) lm(Sepal.Length ~ ., x))  # Pool the results by mice summary(pooled_fit <- pool(models))  #                term   estimate std.error statistic        df      p.value # 1       (Intercept)  2.3343548 0.3244342  7.195157  97.08106 1.314353e-10 # 2       Sepal.Width  0.4715273 0.1041384  4.527891  88.55776 1.848669e-05 # 3      Petal.Length  0.7700316 0.0768588 10.018783 122.02953 1.321441e-17 # 4       Petal.Width -0.2506538 0.1739537 -1.440922  88.10220 1.531513e-01 # 5 Speciesversicolor -0.6648375 0.2940828 -2.260715  81.17797 2.645368e-02 # 6  Speciesvirginica -0.9065327 0.4055137 -2.235517  79.87581 2.817491e-02  # Compare with model on original data summary(lm(Sepal.Length ~ ., data = iris))  # Coefficients: #                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     # (Intercept)        2.17127    0.27979   7.760 1.43e-12 *** # Sepal.Width        0.49589    0.08607   5.761 4.87e-08 *** # Petal.Length       0.82924    0.06853  12.101  < 2e-16 *** # Petal.Width       -0.31516    0.15120  -2.084  0.03889 *   # Speciesversicolor -0.72356    0.24017  -3.013  0.00306 **  # Speciesvirginica  -1.02350    0.33373  -3.067  0.00258 **  # --- # Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #  # Residual standard error: 0.3068 on 144 degrees of freedom # Multiple R-squared:  0.8673,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.8627  # F-statistic: 188.3 on 5 and 144 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

what: How to deal with censored variables?
title: Censored Variables
text: obvious way deal survival variables covariates imputation models. Options discussed (White Royston 2009) include: Use status variable ss (censored) time variable tt. Use ss log(t)\log(t). Use surv(t)\text{surv}(t), , optionally ss. surv(t)\text{surv}(t), denote Nelson-Aalen survival estimate value tt. third option seems attractive explicitly deals censoring information. provide additional details example.

previous_headings: How to deal with censored variables?
title: Censored Variables
text: illustration, use data randomized two-arm trial lung cancer. aim estimate treatment effect “trt” reliable inference using Cox regression. add missing values covariates “age”, “karno”, “diagtime”. Let’s estimate covariate adjusted treatment effect using following steps: Add Nelson-Aalen survival estimates “surv” dataset. Use “surv” well covariates impute missing values covariates multiple times. Perform intended Cox regression imputed data sets. Pool results Rubin’s rule (Rubin 1987), using package {mice} (Buuren Groothuis-Oudshoorn 2011).
code: library(missRanger) library(survival) library(mice)  set.seed(65)  head(veteran)  #   trt celltype time status karno diagtime age prior # 1   1 squamous   72      1    60        7  69     0 # 2   1 squamous  411      1    70        5  64    10 # 3   1 squamous  228      1    60        3  38     0 # 4   1 squamous  126      1    60        9  63    10 # 5   1 squamous  118      1    70       11  65    10 # 6   1 squamous   10      1    20        5  49     0  # 1. Calculate Nelson-Aalen survival probabilities for each time point nelson_aalen <- survfit(Surv(time, status) ~ 1, data = veteran) |>   summary(times = unique(veteran$time)) nelson_aalen <- nelson_aalen[c("time", "surv")]  # Add it to the original data set veteran2 <- merge(veteran, nelson_aalen, all.x = TRUE, by = "time")  # Add missing values to make things tricky veteran2 <- generateNA(veteran2, p = c(age = 0.1, karno = 0.1, diagtime = 0.1))  # 2. Generate 20 complete data sets, representing "time" and "status" by "surv" filled <- replicate(   20,    missRanger(veteran2, . ~ . - time - status, verbose = 0, pmm.k = 10, num.trees = 100),    simplify = FALSE )  # 3. Run a Cox regression for each of the completed data sets models <- lapply(filled, function(x) coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ . - surv, x))  # 4. Pool the results by mice summary(pooled_fit <- pool(models))  #                term     estimate   std.error  statistic       df      p.value # 1               trt  0.231154077 0.214672763  1.0767741 105.1514 2.840454e-01 # 2 celltypesmallcell  0.805824737 0.285571376  2.8217980 114.1273 5.634607e-03 # 3     celltypeadeno  1.130585762 0.306698637  3.6863084 113.3636 3.506786e-04 # 4     celltypelarge  0.340627347 0.296740520  1.1478963 103.4753 2.536583e-01 # 5             karno -0.030623274 0.005653790 -5.4164149 106.3603 3.806255e-07 # 6          diagtime  0.001273007 0.009102230  0.1398566 108.7518 8.890320e-01 # 7               age -0.005587627 0.009379064 -0.5957554 105.3053 5.526170e-01 # 8             prior  0.005174395 0.023433186  0.2208148 112.4847 8.256369e-01  # Compare with the results on the original data summary(coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ ., veteran))$coefficients  #                            coef exp(coef)    se(coef)            z     Pr(>|z|) # trt                2.946028e-01 1.3425930 0.207549604  1.419433313 1.557727e-01 # celltypesmallcell  8.615605e-01 2.3668512 0.275284474  3.129709606 1.749792e-03 # celltypeadeno      1.196066e+00 3.3070825 0.300916994  3.974738536 7.045662e-05 # celltypelarge      4.012917e-01 1.4937529 0.282688638  1.419553530 1.557377e-01 # karno             -3.281533e-02 0.9677173 0.005507757 -5.958020093 2.553121e-09 # diagtime           8.132051e-05 1.0000813 0.009136062  0.008901046 9.928981e-01 # age               -8.706475e-03 0.9913313 0.009300299 -0.936149992 3.491960e-01 # prior              7.159360e-03 1.0071850 0.023230538  0.308187441 7.579397e-01

title: Authors and Citation
text: Michael Mayer. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Mayer M (2025). missRanger: Fast Imputation Missing Values. R package version 2.6.2, https://mayer79.github.io/missRanger/, https://github.com/mayer79/missRanger.
code: @Manual{,   title = {missRanger: Fast Imputation of Missing Values},   author = {Michael Mayer},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 2.6.2, https://mayer79.github.io/missRanger/},   url = {https://github.com/mayer79/missRanger}, }

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values
text: {missRanger} multivariate imputation algorithm based random forests. fast alternative famous ‘MissForest’ algorithm (Stekhoven Buehlmann, 2012), uses {ranger} package (Wright Ziegler, 2017) fit random forests. Since version 2.6.0, --sample application possible.

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values
code: # From CRAN install.packages("missRanger")  # Development version devtools::install_github("mayer79/missRanger")

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values
code: library(missRanger)  set.seed(3)  iris_NA <- generateNA(iris, p = 0.1) head(iris_NA) # Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #         5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #         4.9         3.0          1.4          NA  setosa #         4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #         4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2    <NA> #          NA         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #         5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4    <NA>  iris_filled <- missRanger(iris_NA, pmm.k = 5, num.trees = 100) head(iris_filled)  #   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species # 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa # 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa # 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa # 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa # 5          5.2         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa # 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values
text: algorithm iterates average --bag (OOB) error forests stops improving. missing values filled OOB predictions best iteration, optionally followed predictive mean matching (PMM). PMM step avoids values present original data (like value 0.3334 0-1 coded variable). Furthermore, PMM raises variance resulting conditional distributions realistic level, crucial property multiple imputation. Check-vignettes info, use missRanger() multiple imputation.

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values
text: Stekhoven D. J., Buehlmann, P. (2012). MissForest - non-parametric missing value imputation mixed-type data. Bioinformatics, 28(1), 112-118. Marvin N. Wright, Andreas Ziegler (2017). ranger: Fast Implementation Random Forests High Dimensional Data C++ R. Journal Statistical Software, 77(1), 1-17. doi:10.18637/jss.v077.i01

title: Adds Missing Values — generateNA
text: Takes vector, matrix data.frame replaces values NA.

title: Adds Missing Values — generateNA
code: generateNA(x, p = 0.1, seed = NULL)

title: Adds Missing Values — generateNA
text: x vector, matrix data.frame. p Proportion missing values add x. case x data.frame, p can also vector probabilities per column named vector. seed integer seed.

title: Adds Missing Values — generateNA
text: x missing values.

title: Adds Missing Values — generateNA
code: generateNA(1:10, p = 0.5) #>  [1]  1  2  3 NA NA NA NA  8  9 NA head(generateNA(iris, p = 0.2)) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1           NA         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9          NA          1.4         0.2    <NA> #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3          NA    <NA> #> 4           NA         3.1           NA         0.2  setosa #> 5           NA          NA          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

title: Univariate Imputation — imputeUnivariate
text: Fills missing values vector, matrix data frame sampling replacement non-missing values. data frames, sampling done within column.

title: Univariate Imputation — imputeUnivariate
code: imputeUnivariate(x, v = NULL, seed = NULL)

title: Univariate Imputation — imputeUnivariate
text: x vector, matrix data frame. v character vector column names impute (relevant x data frame). default NULL imputes columns. seed integer seed.

title: Univariate Imputation — imputeUnivariate
text: x imputed values.

title: Univariate Imputation — imputeUnivariate
code: imputeUnivariate(c(NA, 0, 1, 0, 1)) #> [1] 0 0 1 0 1 head(imputeUnivariate(generateNA(iris))) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width    Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2     setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2     setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2     setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         1.9     setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2     setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4 versicolor

what: Fast Imputation of Missing Values by Chained Random Forests — missRanger
title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values by Chained Random Forests — missRanger
text: Uses "ranger" package (Wright & Ziegler) fast missing value imputation chained random forests, see Stekhoven & Buehlmann Van Buuren & Groothuis-Oudshoorn. iterative model fitting, offers option predictive mean matching. firstly avoids imputation values present original data (like value 0.3334 0-1 coded variable). Secondly, predictive mean matching tries raise variance resulting conditional distributions realistic level. allows multiple imputation repeating call missRanger().

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values by Chained Random Forests — missRanger
code: missRanger(   data,   formula = . ~ .,   pmm.k = 0L,   num.trees = 500,   mtry = NULL,   min.node.size = NULL,   min.bucket = NULL,   max.depth = NULL,   replace = TRUE,   sample.fraction = if (replace) 1 else 0.632,   case.weights = NULL,   num.threads = NULL,   save.memory = FALSE,   maxiter = 10L,   seed = NULL,   verbose = 1,   returnOOB = FALSE,   data_only = !keep_forests,   keep_forests = FALSE,   ... )

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values by Chained Random Forests — missRanger
text: data data.frame missing values impute. formula two-sided formula specifying variables imputed (left hand side) variables used impute (right hand side). Defaults . ~ ., .e., use variables impute variables. instance, variables (missings) imputed variables except variable "ID", use . ~ . - ID. Note "." evaluated separately side formula. note variables missings must appear left hand side used right hand side. pmm.k Number candidate non-missing values sample predictive mean matching steps. 0 avoid step. num.trees Number trees passed ranger::ranger(). mtry Number covariates considered per split. default NULL equals rounded root number features. Can function, e.g., function(p) trunc(p/3). Passed ranger::ranger(). Note first iteration, number features growing. Thus, fixed value can lead error. Using function like function(p) min(p, 2) fix problem. min.node.size Minimal node size passed ranger::ranger(). default 1 classification 5 regression. min.bucket Minimal terminal node size passed ranger::ranger(). default NULL means 1. max.depth Maximal tree depth passed ranger::ranger(). NULL means unlimited depth. 1 means single split trees. replace Sample replacement passed ranger::ranger(). sample.fraction Fraction rows per tree passed ranger::ranger(). default: use rows replace = TRUE 0.632 otherwise. case.weights Optional case weights passed ranger::ranger(). num.threads Number threads passed ranger::ranger(). default NULL uses threads. save.memory Slow memory saving mode ranger::ranger(). maxiter Maximum number iterations. seed Integer seed. verbose value 0, 1, 2 controlling verbosity. returnOOB final average OOB prediction errors added data attribute "oob"? relevant data_only = TRUE. data_only TRUE (default), imputed data returned. Otherwise, "missRanger" object additional information returned. keep_forests random forests last relevant iteration returned? default FALSE. Setting option use lot memory. relevant data_only = TRUE. ... Additional arguments passed ranger::ranger(). make sense.

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values by Chained Random Forests — missRanger
text: data_only = TRUE imputed data.frame. Otherwise, "missRanger" object following elements: data: imputed data. data_raw: original data provided. forests: keep_forests = TRUE, list "ranger" models used generate imputed data. NULL otherwise. to_impute: Variables imputed (order). impute_by: Variables used imputation. best_iter: Best iteration. pred_errors: Per-iteration OOB prediction errors (1 - R^2 regression, classification error otherwise). mean_pred_errors: Per-iteration averages OOB prediction errors. pmm.k: input pmm.k.

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values by Chained Random Forests — missRanger
text: iterative chaining stops soon maxiter reached average --bag (OOB) prediction errors stop reducing. latter case, except first iteration, second last (= best) imputed data returned. OOB prediction errors quantified 1 - R^2 numeric variables, classification error otherwise. variable imputed univariately, value 1.

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values by Chained Random Forests — missRanger
text: Wright, M. N. & Ziegler, . (2016). ranger: Fast Implementation Random Forests High Dimensional Data C++ R. Journal Statistical Software, press. <arxiv.org/abs/1508.04409>. Stekhoven, D.J. Buehlmann, P. (2012). 'MissForest - nonparametric missing value imputation mixed-type data', Bioinformatics, 28(1) 2012, 112-118. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btr597. Van Buuren, S., Groothuis-Oudshoorn, K. (2011). mice: Multivariate Imputation Chained Equations R. Journal Statistical Software, 45(3), 1-67. http://www.jstatsoft.org/v45/i03/

title: Fast Imputation of Missing Values by Chained Random Forests — missRanger
Predictive Mean Matching — pmm
text: value prediction vector xtest, one closest k values prediction vector xtrain randomly chosen observed value ytrain returned. Note xtrain xtest must either numeric, logical, factor-valued. ytest can type.

title: Predictive Mean Matching — pmm
code: pmm(xtrain, xtest, ytrain, k = 1L, seed = NULL)

title: Predictive Mean Matching — pmm
text: xtrain Vector predicted values training data. Must numeric, logical, factor-valued. xtest Vector xtrain predicted values test data. Missing values allowed. ytrain Vector observed values training data. Must length xtrain. k Number nearest neighbours (donors) sample . seed Integer random seed.

title: Predictive Mean Matching — pmm
text: Vector length xtest values xtrain.

title: Predict Method — predict.missRanger
text: Impute missing values newdata based object class "missRanger". multivariate imputation, use missRanger(..., keep_forests = TRUE). univariate imputation, forests required. can enforced predict(..., iter = 0) via missRanger(. ~ 1, ...). Note --sample imputation works best rows newdata one missing value (counting missings variables used covariates random forests). call "easy case". "hard case", even multiple iterations (set iter) can lead unsatisfactory results.

title: Predict Method — predict.missRanger
code: # S3 method for class 'missRanger' predict(   object,   newdata,   pmm.k = object$pmm.k,   iter = 4L,   num.threads = NULL,   seed = NULL,   verbose = 1L,   ... )

title: Predict Method — predict.missRanger
text: object 'missRanger' object. newdata data.frame missing values impute. pmm.k Number candidate predictions original dataset predictive mean matching (PMM). default value fitting. iter Number iterations "hard case" rows. 0 univariate imputation. num.threads Number threads used ranger's predict function. default NULL uses threads. seed Integer seed used initial univariate imputation PMM. verbose info printed? (1 = yes/default, 0 ). ... Passed predict function ranger.

title: Predict Method — predict.missRanger
text: --sample algorithm works follows: Impute univariately relevant columns randomly drawing values original unimputed data. step impact "hard case" rows. Replace univariate imputations predictions random forests. done sequentially variables, variables sorted minimize impact univariate imputations. Optionally, followed predictive mean matching (PMM). Repeat Step 2 "hard case" rows multiple times.

title: Print Method — print.missRanger
text: Print method object class "missRanger".

code: # S3 method for class 'missRanger' print(x, ...)

title: missRanger 2.6.2
text: Update code coverage version #86.

title: missRanger 2.6.1
text: CRAN release: 2024-12-07

title: missRanger 2.6.1
text: Solves incompatibility {formula.tools} package. formula.tools:::.character.formula() breaks base::.character() formulas, prevented {missRanger} working, see also https://github.com/decisionpatterns/formula.tools/issues/11. added workaround #81.

title: missRanger 2.6.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-08-17

title: missRanger 2.6.0
text: Fixes major bug, responses used covariates random forests. Thanks reporting @flystar233, see #78. can expect different better imputations.

title: missRanger 2.6.0
text: --sample application now possible! Thanks @jeandigitale pushing idea #58. means can run imp <- missRanger(..., keep_forests = TRUE) apply models new data via predict(imp, newdata). “missRanger” object can saved/loaded binary file, e.g, via saveRDS()/readRDS() later use. Note --sample imputation works best rows newdata one missing value (counting missings variables used covariates random forests). call “easy case”. “hard case”, even multiple iterations (set iter) can lead unsatisfactory results. --sample algorithm works follows: Impute univariately relevant columns randomly drawing values original unimputed data. step impact “hard case” rows. Replace univariate imputations predictions random forests. done sequentially variables, variables sorted minimize impact univariate imputations. Optionally, followed predictive mean matching (PMM). Repeat Step 2 “hard case” rows multiple times.

title: missRanger 2.6.0
text: Columns special type like date/time can’t imputed anymore. need convert numeric imputation. pmm() picky: xtrain xtest must either numeric, logical, factor (identical levels).

title: missRanger 2.6.0
text: Add original data data_raw. Renamed visit_seq to_impute.

title: missRanger 2.6.0
text: Now requires ranger >= 0.16.0. compact vignettes. Better examples README. num.trees = 500 mtry = NULL min.node.size = NULL min.bucket = NULL max.depth = NULL replace = TRUE sample.fraction = (replace) 1 else 0.632 case.weights = NULL num.threads = NULL save.memory = FALSE variables can’t used, information printed. keep_forests = TRUE, argument data_only set FALSE default. “missRanger” object now stores pmm.k. verbose argument passed ranger() well.

title: missRanger 2.5.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-07-12

title: missRanger 2.5.0
text: Since Release 2.3.0, unintentionally, negative formula terms haven’t dropped, see #62. fixed now.

title: missRanger 2.5.0
text: vignette multiple imputations revised, larger number donors predictive mean matching used example.

title: missRanger 2.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-11-19

title: missRanger 2.4.0
text: New argument data_only = TRUE control imputed data returned (default), object class “missRanger”. object contains imputed data infos like OOB prediction errors, fixing #28. value FALSE later becoming default {missRanger 3.0.0}. announced via deprecation cycle.

title: missRanger 2.4.0
text: New argument keep_forests = FALSE. random forests best iteration (one generated final imputed data) added “missRanger” object? Note use lot memory. relevant data_only = FALSE. solves #54.

title: missRanger 2.4.0
text: case algorithm converge, data last iteration returned instead current one. fixed.

title: missRanger 2.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-10-20

title: missRanger 2.3.0
text: missRanger() now works syntactically wrong variable names like “1bad:variable”. solves old issue, recently popping new issue. missRanger() now works number features, long formula left default, .e., . ~ .. solves issue.

title: missRanger 2.3.0
text: Documentation improvement. ranger() now called via x/y interface, formula interface anymore.

title: missRanger 2.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-04-28 Switch importFrom :: code style Documentation improved

title: missRanger 2.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-03-24

title: missRanger 2.2.0
text: Removed {mice} “suggested” packages. Removed {dplyr} “suggested” packages. Removed {survival} “suggested” packages.

title: missRanger 2.2.0
text: Adding Github pages. Introduction Github actions.

title: missRanger 2.1.5 (not on CRAN)
text: Maintenance release, switching testthat 3, changing package structure, bringing vignettes right order.

title: missRanger 2.1.4 (not on CRAN)
text: Now using progress bar instead “.” show progress (verbose = 1).

title: missRanger 2.1.2 and 2.1.3
text: Fixing failing unit tests.

title: missRanger 2.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2021-03-20

title: missRanger 2.1.1
text: Allow use “mtry” suggested Thomas Lumley. Recommended values NULL (default), 1 function number covariables m, e.g. mtry = function(m) max(1, m %/% 3). Keep mind missRanger() might use growing set covariables first iteration process, passing mtry = 2 might result error.

title: missRanger 2.1.1
text: Improved help pages. Splitted long vignette three shorter ones.

title: missRanger 2.1.1
text: Added unit tests.

title: missRanger 2.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2019-06-30 summary changes since version 1.x.x.

title: missRanger 2.1.0
text: missRanger now also imputes uses logical variables, character variables variables mode numeric like dates times. Added formula interface specify variables impute (left hand side) used (right hand side). (pseudo) examples: . ~ . (default): Use variables impute variables. Note missing values imputed. Variables without missings used impute others. . ~ . - ID: Use variables except ID impute missing values. Species ~ Sepal.Width: Use Sepal.Width impute Species. works Sepal.Width contain missing values. (Add right hand side .) Species + Sepal.Length ~ Species + Petal.Length: Use Species Petal.Length impute Species Sepal.Length. works Petal.Length contain missing values appear left hand side therefore imputed . . ~ 1: Univariate imputation relevant columns (nothing selected right hand side). first argument generateNA called x instead data consistency imputeUnivariate. imputeUnivariate now also works data frames matrices. PMM mode, missRanger relies OOB predictions. smaller value num.trees, higher risk missing OOB predictions, caused error PMM. Now, pmm allows missing values xtrain ytrain. Thus, algorithm even work num.trees = 1. useful impute large data sets PMM.

title: missRanger 2.1.0
text: function imputeUnivariate received seed argument. function imputeUnivariate received v argument, specifying columns impute. function generateNA offers now possibility use different proportions missings column. verbose 0, missRanger show variables imputed order variables used imputation.

title: missRanger 2.1.0
text: argument returnOOB now effectively controlling --bag errors attached attribute “oob” resulting data frame . far, always attached.
